Award.AwardTitle: CSR:Small: Energy Harvesting for Performance Sensitive Wireless Sensor Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project addresses energy issues in sensor systems. Energy harvesting permits wireless sensor network (WSN) applications to extract and store energy from the environment. Certain evolving application classes, particularly those supporting critical infrastructures like long-term monitoring and surveillance systems, require higher levels of communication and computational performance. Often, systems in this application class must be able to provide robust and flexible responses to unforeseen or emergency situations. Many of these proposed applications will also be required to run autonomously for years or even decades, and therefore may require energy harvesting techniques.

Current methods for WSN-based energy harvesting typically do not provide a coordinated energy management policy for this class of applications. This project addresses this gap in three ways. First, the team is designing and evaluating a set of optimal energy harvesting policies that combine dynamic voltage scaling (changing the CPU speed) with dynamic modulation scaling (changing wireless transmission rates.) The algorithms efficiently support time-critical applications that have a wide range of workloads while maintaining necessary energy reserves in order to deal with emergency situations. Second, is the development of distributed protocols to implement these algorithms. Finally, is the development of prototypes of two energy harvesting hardware testbeds, a flow-based water energy generation system and a solar-based energy harvester used in a hybrid robotic sensor network application. The two prototype testbeds will not only yield critical technical insight but will introduce students of various backgrounds into the issues of networking, device, and robotic design.

The PIs have a multi-step plan to integrate their research and education mission of their proposal. This includes development of new courses, expanding and strengthening the schools effort on energy management, developing week-long training camps for high school instructors through the STEM program, and contributing to the advancement of the GMU robotics and sensor labs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs) are a critical enabling technology for many emerging Internet-of-Things (IoT) applications.  Due to limited energy supplies, efficient energy management for WSNs has long been a primary concern of researchers. As part of this ongoing activity there is much interest in designing and implementing energy harvesting solutions for WSN systems by extracting and storing energy from the environment. Examples include solar and wind driven systems. Despite this work there have been relatively few efforts towards understanding how to design systems that require both performance sensitive operation and energy harvesting modules as the power supply source.


This project helped fill the knowledge gap between predictable and performance sensitive design and the need to deploy WSN systems requiring energy harvesting. In terms of algorithmic design, the focus of our work was to develop techniques that traded off performance with energy consumption by tuning and modifying the modulation level for wireless transmission, via Dynamic Modulation Scaling, and the voltage level used for processing, via Dynamic Voltage Scaling.  Using these methods we developed algorithms that meet all performance objectives while minimizing energy consumption, and applied these results to applications that have probabilistic workloads or communicate with a base station as part of a cluster.  We also developed a hybrid link access method that supports energy conversation with distributed slot reclaiming.    In terms of protocol design we developed an epoch-oriented control plane management system that combined contention-oriented and contention-free time periods to ensure route stability and coordinated node hardware settings.  We also developed a one-to-many broadcast protocol for massively scaled (thousands of nodes) systems.  In terms of implementation, in support of our research ideas we wrote, deployed and experimented with software for operation in a local testbed of dozens of nodes and a remote testbed of hundreds of nodes. 


Many current IoT applications in safety-critical, medical and industrial domains involve energy management and energy harvesting, while the support of energy efficiency infrastructure development has long been a national priority. By coupling the satisfaction of performance objectives with energy harvesting, the algorithms, protocols and software designed for this project have the potential to greatly enhance IoT applications by supporting the growth of  embedded and cyberphysical systems that are environmentally friendly.
